body: Thanks!
Rebased and aligned to  #595; development commits squashed down to one commit.

The code is fine ("does no harm"). 

There is discussion on the JIRA ticket. https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/JENA-1751

I am curious as to why varargs is useful in practice because the call site has to have a fixed number of arguments, or manage a separate Java array, and if it's an array, a (collections) list and "foreach" works, and that which leads me to wonder about the relationship with jena-querybuilder.

Recorded as [JENA-1754](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/JENA-1754).

Thank you!

> Recorded as [JENA-1754](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/JENA-1754).

Thanks - I should have done the ticket, but had login issues which I've now resolved.
Second commit does the removal of the tests for graph statistics handler.  They are for graph-mem and union graph when the components are all graph-mem.

I think there are deprecation annotations missing from permissions code.
But I am traveling and can not check.

Done and added the second commit - just a couple of uses.
Improved JavaDoc for `ExprFactory` and `UpdateBuilder` is still missing.
The changes are fine but I think that there might need to be more documentation in the package info describing things like how to get a ExprFactory and providing examples of how to use it.

Ps: Jackson 2.9.10 being released too... I think it is a dependency in jena? Just in case you'd like to look at changelog and see if there's any reason to update it too for next release https://twitter.com/fasterxml/status/1175466334852747264?s=20

Thanks for pointing that out. It's been bumpy for upgrades these last few months.

We have a upstream dependency for Jackson for jsonld-java. I don't think any of Jena code directly uses the Jackson code. Now, Jena and jsonld-java don't actually use the part of databind that has been under attack, but it is easy to upgrade so if jena uses use jackson directly, they get the fixes.

jsonld-java is currently depending on 2.9.9 (core) and 2.9.9.2 (databind). Jena takes control of the exact version because of the releases for CVE's, giving us fine grained control (2.9.9.x) without needing to wait for jsonld-java to release, assuming x.x.x.+1 is fix-only.

In my $job, some customers scan jars and match against the CVE database. I'm sure they aren't the only ones. It is easier to upgrade that explain why the CVE does not affect the code.

Given [JENA-1760 "Retire Apache Jena maven-tools module"](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/JENA-1760), we can close this PR. 

The PR is not lost - it can be revived at some later date.
Thanks. JENA-1755 is still open to track any further changes.

There has been great discussion and analysis here.

The code has moved on, possibly even making it easier to have query caching and update invalidation by any route (e.g GSP, or support of custom services)

At the same time, security is now available in Fuseki itself for server/service/endpoint and graph. That makes caching harder.

I suggest we close this PR. The discussion will still be here.
@afs Thank you for sharing your feedback. I have closed the PR.

Jackson 2.9.10 (core and databind) has hit central and the automated GH security alerts.

JENA-1762.
This is "git mv" and fixed up the test driver code.
I'll hold back from merging this until after 3.13.1.  It is a functionality change.
Wrong JIRA number.

I don't remember either. There is a case when there's a projection, but I can't find a reason not to when there is no projection.  If it had a projection which writes out the vars, it becomes a success on the other if-branch.
Rationale: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/JENA-1779

Reading the wider context of the code it looks like the new code path replaces the old code path and the only way to use the old code path would be to extend the class and override the relevant method to call the old method.  Except that you can't do that because some/all of the methods are `private`, can we make them all `protected` to leave users the option to customise behaviour if they need to?

Yes - this can cause an OOME. The only option to work with connection caching I can see are chunking or the in-memory serialization. This code path is used when the graph/dataset is a Java object. 

`graphToHttpEntity` and `datasetToHttpEntity`, the points where a customisation should override are both protected. This is the right way to customize.

The path of loading a (large) file into a remote triplestore is different code path and it sets the length from the file using httpClient `FileEntity` which sets the Content-Length from the file.

I don't like the idea of protected on the old code because it is broken in almost all cases of use in more than one transfer. I left it "for the record" and to have the method comment that this does not work over cached connections. "protected" seems encourage usage. I don't mind changing to protected from private but leaving code (3 lines) that will normally go wrong does not feel like a good idea. At least it can be copied (open source!) YMMV. 

@rvesse - do you have a usage that is sending a large amount of data via this code path?

OK, I won't notify you again about this release, but will get in touch when a new version is available. If you'd rather skip all updates until the next major or minor version, let me know by commenting `@dependabot ignore this major version` or `@dependabot ignore this minor version`.

If you change your mind, just re-open this PR and I'll resolve any conflicts on it.

This needs a workaround to [THRIFT-5022](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-5022) (as per apache/thrift#1942).

It looks like `BinRDF.apply` can work without using isOpen.

PR #635 includes this commit and workarounds needed because of a Thrift regression [THRIFT-5022](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-5022).

Closing this - the change will get made via #635 -  thanks!
Agree. Thank you for your suggestion.
Thank you!

Fixed in #645
A better fix, keeping the nonPresent cache
Recorded as https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/JENA-1792
PR merged - thank you!

Thank you for your warm words.

I totally agree with your suggestions. 
There's no need to check dataVersion indeed. In principle, we don't even need to store a whole transaction or have a separate field for hasActiveWriteTransaction, it could be just one `AtomicReference<Thread> writingThread`.

I introduced explicit synchronization because I was afraid of a potential race condition. Without synchronization in `notifyTxnStart` a new write transaction can be started immediately after you check hasActiveWriteTransaction:
```
 // in a read transaction
 if ( notPresent != null && inTopLevelTxn()) // inTopLevelTxn() == true
 // a new write transaction is started in another thread, making the read transaction not top level anymore
                notPresent.put(node, Boolean.TRUE);
```
However, it seems to be no problem. Even if a new write transaction is started, it will not be able to allocate a new node while the lock is being held by the read transaction.

Good idea.

If you update the PR, we are ready to put this in.

I'll go and update/clean up the comments once it's in separately.

(The transaction mechanism itself will ensure there is only one write transaction.)
Sure
Merged - thanks for the contribution!

Hi @georgschmidtdumont -- looks good.

Is this taken from the Xerces2-j code base, v2.12.? branch xml-schema-1.1-dev? If possible that would be good to try to align the source code - but they may be there is a reason why not?

Hi @afs ,

I did not take this from the Xerces2-j code base. I had a look at the Xerces code base and there a one or two small differences in the Xerces implementation and this implementation. I tried to align the code and it is not entirely possible at the moment since the `isXMLSchema11` flag in the `parse` method is not available in Jena implementation.
Since this flag is added in the xml-schema-1.1-dev branch in Xerces and this branch is not merged or has a PR I would suggest using the implementation in this PR and update it once the xml-schema-1.1-dev branch has been merged.
I hope this is not a blocker for this PR.

Do you know why the Xerces classes are duplicated in Jena instead of pulling Xerces as a dependency?

I've confirmed the problem and also checked it generates a violation running it at the [SHACL playground](https://shacl.org/playground/).

The fix works as well - there are two unused imports after the change. It would be good if those were cleaned up.

The test under "std" are a copy of the W3C test suite from the working group so I think it is better to leave them untouched and add a test under the "src/test/resources/local" area.

The tests are driven from a use of RDF defined by the SHACL WG using manifests and test cases; it has its own unique style. I've taken RDF from the test case the JIRA ticket and turned it into PR #653 . 

Please remove the test file and I'll add the other PR at the same time as this one. If you could confirm I've correctly extracted the test case, that would be great.

With the fix here, the test case passes; without the fix it fails.
Thanks for reviewing. I've removed the unused imports and the extra test case. Please also take a look at my comments on your PR.
Both done, using `target-class-subclass-1` then PR squashed to one commit.

Jena uses Xerces code for the datatypes and used to have dependency on Xerces. That does mean that the XML parser used is Xerces because it wires itself in if on the classpath. 

Sometimes people want to use a different parser when incorporated into a larger application, and a fixed dependency gets in the way with OSGi sometimes. So to reduce size and isolate Jena's specific needs, we pulled the code out JENA-1537.

The JDK has its own XML parser - a older xerces but one which has been significantly modified since.

The list of unused imports noted by Eclipse:

    The import org.apache.jena.arq.querybuilder.ExprFactory is never used
    WhereClauseTest.java
    
    The import org.apache.jena.arq.querybuilder.SelectBuilder is never used
    WhereClause.java

    The import org.apache.jena.sparql.lang.sparql_11.ParseException is never used
    AbstractQueryBuilderTest.java
    
    The import org.junit.Test is never used
    WhereClauseTest.java

@Claudenw Would it be possible to format "JENA-NNNN: ...." for the PR? Then the JIRA ticket is automatically updated.
These changes are in place.  I assume this is to correct issues before moving them to the jena-examples project.  Is that corect?

The changes are orthogonal to whether to move or not.

There were comments on email and on JENA-1806 so let's discuss the details there.

The idea of moving the examples is good - needs some details and refinement next.
Nice! Nothing comes to time as to why it would be faster except external things - maven causes network and server usage.
I presume this is fixing some kind of potential performance pitfall?  Some explanation of why this change is necessary would be helpful to understand the context of this PR
To avoid excessively long execution times, MaxBasicQueries limits the generation of queries to 1024. In some cases, this limit is too low.

See the [comment on the JENA_1812](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/JENA-1812). This changes the length of blank node output in N-Triples, going from 32 to 64 hex digits.. The suggestion is to use Murmur3_128, this is the same length as MD5.

Great. Thanks for the quick response.

Turns out it has happened before:
https://builds.apache.org/job/Jena_Development_Deploy/org.apache.jena$jena-tdb2/1792/testReport/junit/org.apache.jena.tdb2.store/TestTransactionLifecycleTDB/transaction_concurrency_writer/

(other failures around that time were unrelated Jenkins related matters)

Both the Apache Commons and Google Guava impls are translations of the C++ code. I think (maybe Claude can confirm) that the "x86" in the method names is because Java uses the same endian-ness as x86. But maybe the int->long conversions are different - one of the two fixes in codec 1.14 is about int to long which in Java (signed numbers) does a sign extension.

There are 4 implementations of Murmur3:  There are 32 and 128 bit implementations both available in x86 and x64 variants.  The x86 and x64 variants are turned for different platforms but return different values.  The version available in commons-codec is murmur3-x86-128.

The recent fix in commons-codec was a sign extension bug in seeds wherein if the seed was negative the conversion from int to long was not masked allowing the sign to extend across the upper bytes and changing the result with respect to the "C" code.  The name was also changed to reflect the actual hashing method being implemented.

Andy, 

Since this changes the pom.xml for the GeoSPARQL module I thought you might want to check over and test.

Thanks,

Greg

Closed in favour of #673 (use murmur3 128 bit because it is the same length as MD5).

@NSeydoux - thanks for suggesting the change.
The assumption that null is not registered is correct.
Thanks for the quick review and approval @afs. I'll wait a few more days before merging, in case others want to comment.

> I would absolutely use this once it becomes part of a release

Which way round Jena operating as the CommonsRDF provider, or Jena code calling through CommonsRDF?

>> I would absolutely use this once it becomes part of a release

> Which way round Jena operating as the CommonsRDF provider, or Jena code calling through CommonsRDF?

The first method: I have library code that uses the CommonsRDF API and at present, the provider (via ServiceLoader) is JenaRDF (commons-rdf-jena), but I would immediately replace that with what you have here. I would also use this code as a bridge between the Jena-specific RDF processing (e.g. RDFParser) and the CommonsRDF APIs.

It would also be nice if this code had a `./src/main/resources/META-INF/services/org.apache.commons.rdf.api.RDF` file containing this line:

    org.apache.jena.commonsrdf.JenaRDF

That way, one could use this with the service loader.
ServiceLoader resource file added. I have put in a test although it is test setup dependent (both "simple" and "jena" implementations are in-scope).

I'm thinking that anyone looking back on this in the future may want to understand it and the test case is the illustration.

Is there a simpler test case? (it does not need to be CONSTRUCT for example). Are all the WHERE clause parts necessary?
I'll leave the decision to you. After all, the next person to read it may well be future-you!

I've simplified the test slightly by removing a couple of unnecessary patterns, and cleaned it up by removing the escaped tabs in the query. Also added a comment to say why it is necessary.

Test has been checked to ensure that it fails with the previous version of the transformer, so is a valid test of the issue that is being fixed.
Would you like me to merge this?
@grahamtriggs  - thank you!
@afs Sure, you can merge this, thanks! I could probably do that myself too but I haven't done this for awhile and I think the processes might have changed.

Yes, it's changed. Press the big green button, resolve or update the JIRA ticket. 

Now that the GH and the ASF repos are both write mode, and mirrored, the git updating can be done on either. i.e. GH tools work.

FYI, OSGi support can be added by using this maven configuration (in place of the `maven-jar-plugin` above -- that would no longer be needed):

```xml
  <build>
    <plugins>
      <plugin>
        <groupId>org.apache.felix</groupId>
        <artifactId>maven-bundle-plugin</artifactId>
        <extensions>true</extensions>
        <configuration>
          <instructions>
            <Automatic-Module-Name>org.apache.jena.commonsrdf</Automatic-Module-Name>
            <Bundle-DocURL>https://jena.apache.org</Bundle-DocURL>
            <Bundle-SymbolicName>org.apache.jena.commonsrdf</Bundle-SymbolicName>
            <Export-Package>org.apache.jena.commonsrdf;version=${project.version}</Export-Package>
            <Import-Package>*</Import-Package>
            <Provide-Capability>osgi.serviceloader; osgi.serviceloader=org.apache.commons.rdf.api.RDF</Provide-Capability>
            <Require-Capability>osgi.extender; filter:="(osgi.extender=osgi.serviceloader.registrar)";resolution:=optional</Require-Capability>
          </instructions>
        </configuration>
      </plugin>
    </plugins>
  </build>
```

And also setting the packaging type to `bundle`:

     <packaging>bundle</packaging>

With this configuration, the `<automatic.module.name>org.apache.jena.commonsrdf</automatic.module.name>` property isn't used, but if you'd prefer, that property can be interpolated in the maven-bundle-plugin config. (You will notice that the Java11 Automatic-Module-Name will be included in the MANIFEST.MF)

1,2,3 - yes. And thanks for the PR to the PR branch.

(I had forgotten automatic-module-name isn't inherited from the parent POM, requiring configuring the jar-plugin in each module.)

Re:OSGi - wouldn't that be better as part of apache-jena-osgi?

Re: OSGi - either way is fine by me. I wasn't sure if you wanted to keep the commonsrdf module separate, since it's part of `-extras`, but putting it all into `jena-osgi` has an appealing simplicity (and it should be simple to add it to the `jena-osgi` module; just make sure the `Provide-Capability` and `Require-Capability` entries are present).

I wasn't expecting it to be used quite so quickly! 

"jena-extras" has morphed a bit; it is not a few bits and pieces of interest, it's "things one level deeper in the directory hierarchy".

Done all the Java changes, and added all the extra stuff it implies. At the moment the POM is "jar". 

For OSGi, my mild preference is to put it in apache-jena-osgi so that all OSGi related stuff is together.

Would it be OK to merge as "jar", and continue the discussion for later changes?

> For OSGi, my mild preference is to put it in apache-jena-osgi so that all OSGi related stuff is together.

Yes, that makes sense

> Would it be OK to merge as "jar", and continue the discussion for later changes?

Yes, sounds good.

I am encountering a problem with this.

mvn: 3.6.3

The commons-rdf-api:tests artifact does not have a version and the commons-rdf-simple artifact has `${ver.commonsrdf}`. These seem to be needed in /pom.xml.

      <dependency>
        <groupId>org.apache.commons</groupId>
        <artifactId>commons-rdf-api</artifactId>
        <version>${ver.commonsrdf}</version>
        <classifier>tests</classifier>
      </dependency>

      <dependency>
        <groupId>org.apache.commons</groupId>
        <artifactId>commons-rdf-simple</artifactId>
        <version>${ver.commonsrdf}</version>
      </dependency>

@osma : when convenient, could you review this please?

I tried to add you as a reviewer but your GH name wasn't an option. One possibility is that your account isn't linked to the Apache Github organisation : https://gitbox.apache.org/setup/
Interesting. I thought the `dependencyManagement` would have taken care of this, but I've adjusted the PR to be more explicit about the commons rdf dependencies

I should have been clearer - the build problem I'm getting is in the jena-commonsrdf module. Didn't get to jena-osgi because jena-commonsrdf didn't build. The explicit versions shouldn't be necessary. 

The real problem is the commons-rdf-api:tests. The "simple" issue is a red herring.

It seems that defining in the dependencyManagement of the parent for the main artifact does not apply to `<classifier>test` -- this may be related to being in `<scope>test`.

In jena-commonsrdf/pom.xml:

    <dependency>
      <groupId>org.apache.commons</groupId>
      <artifactId>commons-rdf-api</artifactId>
      <version>${ver.commonsrdf}</version>
      <classifier>tests</classifier>
    </dependency>

works and, to me, looks tidier than in the root /pom.xml.
Does that [last commit](https://github.com/apache/jena/pull/684/commits/737a6e0800cf102ac087ee81df8123dcff5d9fb0) work for you? I upgraded to maven 3.6.3 locally, and it builds for me.

It is `<scope>test` items causing build problems. The default scope dependencyManagement works fine.
